channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Purge Set to Force Out More Top Homeland Security Officials
item.media:description: President Trump sought the resignation of the director of the Secret Service, and more Department of Homeland Security officials were expected to leave soon.
item.description: As the president expressed frustration with his own administration, the top echelon of the department managing border security and other matters was being hollowed out.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER, MAGGIE HABERMAN, NICHOLAS FANDOS and ZOLAN KANNO-YOUNGS

item.title: Trump Signals Even Fiercer Immigration Agenda, With a Possible Return of Family Separations
item.media:description: Migrants entering a Border Patrol vehicle in Sunland Park, N.M. last month. More than 2,700 children were separated from their parents at the border under Mr. Trump’s “zero tolerance” policy.
item.description: The longer-term effect of the eruption of Oval Office frustration is likely to be a burst of anti-immigrant policies that stand out, even for Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR, ZOLAN KANNO-YOUNGS and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: Chinese Woman Arrested at Mar-a-Lago Had a Hidden Camera Detector, Prosecutors Say
item.media:description: The Chinese woman who was arrested after gaining entry to President Trump’s Mar-a-Lago resort appeared in court on Monday.
item.description: Yujing Zhang, 32, was allowed into President Trump’s resort by Secret Service agents, but was later arrested. The authorities said she also had large amounts of cash in her hotel room.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Boeing’s 737 Max: 1960s Design, 1990s Computing Power and Paper Manuals
item.media:description: The Boeing 737, in 1968, the year after it was christened. Boeing pitched the plane as a smaller alternative to its larger jets, earning it the nickname the “Baby Boeing.”
item.description: The Boeing jet that crashed twice in five months relied on decades-old systems and left pilots without some common safety features.
item.dc:creator: JACK NICAS and JULIE CRESWELL
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: News Analysis: In Trump, Netanyahu Sees an Ally Who Helps Him Push the Envelope
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel last month at the White House with President Trump. Mr. Trump has wrapped Mr. Netanyahu in a warm embrace from the beginning of his presidency.
item.description: President Trump has given Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the political cover to embrace a position that critics say would all but extinguish the dream of a viable Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Why Some Israelis Still Support Netanyahu
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is caught up in a corruption scandal that has clouded his campaign ahead of Tuesday’s election, but some Israelis still support him. We went there to understand why they are sticking with him.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Talk of West Bank Annexations Is a Blow to Peace but No Surprise, Palestinians Say
item.media:description: Laborers at a construction site in the Israeli settlement of Beitar Illit in the West Bank on Sunday.
item.description: Absorbing Jewish settlements on the West Bank into Israel could draw violent reactions, Arabs warn, but it would also confirm what they think is Israel’s goal.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Felicity Huffman and 13 Others to Plead Guilty in College Admissions Scandal
item.media:description: Felicity Huffman left a federal court hearing in Boston earlier this month.
item.media:credit: Sarah Rice for The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Huffman is the best-known figure to admit wrongdoing in the investigation, which found faked test scores, phony athletic credentials and big payments.
item.dc:creator: KATE TAYLOR

item.title: Olympic Cyclist Kelly Catlin Seemed Destined for Glory. Then She Killed Herself.
item.media:description: Kelly Catlin’s brother, Colin, sifts through the belongings retrieved from her graduate student apartment at Stanford, hoping for clues explaining why she took her life last month at age 23.
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.description: Catlin was lining up for a shot at Olympic gold. And an elite mathematical mind would open opportunities off the track. But torment lurked behind the success.
item.dc:creator: JULIET MACUR

item.title: Virginia Beats Texas Tech in OT to Claim Its First N.C.A.A. Title
item.media:description: Kyle Guy helped lead Virginia to its first N.C.A.A. championship.
item.description: The Cavaliers completed a yearlong march to redemption after ending the 2018 season as the first No. 1 seed to lose to a No. 16 in the men’s tournament.
item.dc:creator: BILLY WITZ

item.title: Homeland Security, Israel, Church Fires: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA KANNAPELL and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: President Trump and Kirstjen Nielsen visiting the new border wall in Calexico, Calif., on Friday.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC

item.title: Cancel Kirstjen Nielsen
item.description: Her role in terrorizing children should make her a permanent pariah.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE GOLDBERG

item.title: At Long Last, a Glimpse of a Black Hole
item.media:description: Jon Han
item.description: This week scientists are expected to release images of the silhouette of this elusive and inscrutable astronomical object.
item.dc:creator: PRIYAMVADA NATARAJAN

item.title: Subpoena Isn’t the Only Way to Get the Mueller Report
item.description: By law, the House and Senate Intelligence Committees should already have certain investigative materials relating to Russian election meddling.
item.dc:creator: VICKI DIVOLL

item.title: People Can Savage Social Norms, but Also Revive Them
item.media:description: Cass Sunstein's new book puts norms at the center of how we think about change.
item.media:credit: Shawn Brackbill for The New York Times
item.description: Individuals can change the way we see.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BROOKS

item.title: Why Does Trump Want to Debase the Fed?
item.media:description: Flags flying above the Federal Reserve building in Washington.
item.description: The tax cut fizzled; send in the clowns!
item.dc:creator: PAUL KRUGMAN

item.title: Who Is Left to Say No to Trump?
item.media:description: Kirstjen Nielsen at the White House last June with President Trump and Vice President Pence, for the signing of an executive order meant to end the separation of families at the border.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Kirstjen Nielsen is the latest one out of the president’s spiraling cabinet who expressed his cruelty but wouldn’t go as far as he wanted.
item.dc:creator: JAMELLE BOUIE
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: To Reform the Police, Target Their Union Contract
item.description: We did this in Austin and won.
item.dc:creator: SUKYI MCMAHON and CHAS MOORE

item.title: The Stone: The End of Satire
item.media:description: Detail from an exhibit of children’s drawings sent to the Charlie Hebdo office after the 2015 terrorist attack.
item.description: The toxic disinformation of social media has rendered traditional forms of humor quaint and futile.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN E.H. SMITH

item.title: The N.F.L.’s Great Cherry Tree Caper
item.media:description: Public outcry disrupted plans to cut down cherry trees in Nashville to make space for an event for the NFL.
item.description: The league didn’t actually try to steal Nashville’s gorgeous cherry trees, but it sure felt that way.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET RENKL

item.title: Latin America Is Already Trump’s 2020 Presidential Campaign Testing Ground
item.media:description: President Trump speaking about immigration and border security in Calexico, Calif., on Friday.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: The U.S. president needs to keep cooperating closely with Mexico, steer clear of any military action in Venezuela and refrain from bullying his partners and allies in the region.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SHIFTER

item.title: Iran Should Reconcile With America
item.media:description: A woman in Qazvin, Iran, in February.
item.description: Isn’t it time to abandon the policies that have kept the people of Iran and the United States apart since 1979?
item.dc:creator: BRIAN H. HOOK

item.title: The Rise and Rise of the Turkish Right
item.media:description: Mansur Yavas campaigning for mayor in Ankara, Turkey, in March.
item.media:credit: Rasit Aydogan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: The opposition parties challenging President Recep Tayyip Erdogan offer another version of the right-wing nationalism of his party and its nationalist partner.
item.dc:creator: HALIL M. KARAVELI
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: With ‘Unplanned,’ Abortion Opponents Turn Toward Hollywood
item.media:description: Ashley Bratcher, left, in “Unplanned,” where she portrays Abby Johnson, a former director of a Planned Parenthood clinic who became an abortion-rights opponent.
item.description: The makers of the divisive anti-abortion movie — a word-of-mouth hit that a physician called misleading — say they’ve been shunned by mainstream media.
item.dc:creator: REGGIE UGWU

item.title: The Saturday Profile: An Arabic-Speaking Talk-Show Host Wades Into Germany’s Culture Wars
item.media:description: As the host of a popular Arabic language talk show on German television, Jaafar Abdul Karim has presided over thousands of difficult discussions.
item.description: Jafaar Abdul Karim is not afraid to take on issues that many Muslim refugees in the country consider taboo. And, yes, he has had death threats.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Metropolitan Diary: ‘I Really Just Wanted the Comfort of My Husband’s Being There’
item.description: Asking for flowers before having surgery, help hailing a cab on East Houston Street and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.

item.title: Trump Designates Iran’s Revolutionary Guards a Foreign Terrorist Group
item.media:description: Members of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps in Tehran this year. President Trump said the designation “will significantly expand the scope and scale of our maximum pressure on the Iranian regime.”
item.description: The designation is the first one by the United States against part of a foreign government. The Pentagon and C.I.A. oppose the move, citing risks to Americans.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Trump Ends Deal Between M.L.B. and Cuban Baseball Federation
item.media:description: Los Leneros de las Tunas, a Cuban baseball team, before a Caribbean Series game in Panama City in February.
item.description: The Trump administration declared that the deal violated trade laws because the Cuban federation was part of the government in Havana.
item.dc:creator: DAVID WALDSTEIN and MICHAEL TACKETT
item.category: Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)

item.title: Eric Swalwell, California Congressman, Is Running for President
item.media:description: Representative Eric Swalwell announced on Monday that he is running for president.
item.description: Mr. Swalwell, a member of the House Intelligence and Judiciary Committees, has gained notoriety as a critic of President Trump’s foreign and immigration policies.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE ASTOR

item.title: Powerful Storm Threatens More Misery in Flood-Hit Midwest
item.media:description: Flooding in the town of Hamburg, Iowa, on March 20. A powerful storm this week is expected to dump significant snow and rain on farms and floodplains that are still struggling to recover from last month’s historic storm.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: The system is expected to dump significant snow and rain this week on a region that is still struggling to recover from devastating floods.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

item.title: Maryland Man Planned to Run Down Pedestrians at National Harbor, U.S. Says
item.media:description: The National Harbor in Maryland. Federal prosecutors say a 28-year-old man planned to run down pedestrians on the waterfront in an ISIS-inspired attack.
item.description: Federal prosecutors say Rondell Henry, 28, was inspired by an ISIS attack in Nice, France, in 2016. He has been charged with interstate transportation of a stolen vehicle.
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Hopes Raised During the Arab Spring Are Being Revived Across North Africa
item.media:description: Protesters rally in front of the military headquarters in Khartoum, the capital of Sudan, on Monday.
item.description: The uprisings of 2011 are inspiring a new generation to challenge entrenched, authoritarian leaders, raising hopes as well as doubts about the future.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Supreme Council of the Armed Forces (Egypt)

item.title: Culture of Secrecy Shields Hospitals With Outbreaks of Drug-Resistant Infections
item.media:description: The C.D.C. made a public announcement when an antibiotic-resistant form of the rod-shaped Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria sickened several American travelers to Tijuana, Mexico. But it does not reveal which hospitals in the United States are battling infectious outbreaks.
item.media:credit: Janice Haney Carr/Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.description: The lack of transparency puts patients at risk, some say. Institutions say disclosure could scare some people away from seeking needed medical care.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS and MATT RICHTEL
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Pompeo Bars 16 Saudis From U.S. in Response to Khashoggi Killing
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in January at the Royal Court in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
item.description: The list included one of Prince Mohammed’s closest aides, but not the prince himself, despite U.S. intelligence agencies concluding he was responsible for sending the team to kill Jamal Khashoggi.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: 9 Hong Kong Democracy Advocates Convicted for Role in 2014 Protests
item.media:description: Nine democracy activists posed for photographers before entering a court in Hong Kong on Tuesday.
item.description: Nine activists, including three founders of a group that called for civil disobedience, are facing up to seven years in prison on public nuisance charges.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Kick-Start Your Reading Habit With Bite-Sized Books
item.description: If you don’t feel like you have the time to read more, or struggle to finish a book, this method will help. If you have time for Twitter or Instagram, you have time for these books.
item.dc:creator: HARRY GUINNESS

item.title: How to Mount a TV Without Making a Mess
item.description: Don’t underestimate the time and energy it takes to mount your TV on the wall yourself. Here’s how to do it and keep your wall — and your peace of mind — in one piece.
item.dc:creator: GANDA SUTHIVARAKOM

item.title: How to Deal With a Jerk Without Being a Jerk
item.description: It’s natural to get defensive, but that only escalates the cycle of aggression.
item.dc:creator: ADAM GRANT

item.title: Crowdwise: What to Say (and What Not to Say) to Someone Who’s Grieving
item.description: A little empathy goes a long way, especially when someone is recovering from the loss of a loved one. Unfortunately, even when some of us mean well, we make the situation worse. Here’s how to avoid it.
item.dc:creator: DAVID POGUE

item.title: How to Tap Less on Your Phone (but Get More Done)
item.description: Most of us spend hours each day tapping the glass of our smartphones. But what if you could do just as much — maybe more — and give your fingers a break?
item.dc:creator: DAVID POGUE

item.title: Lens: Photos of Lesbian Lives Meant to Inspire a Movement
item.description: Joan E. Biren began to photograph at a time when it was almost impossible to find authentic images of lesbians and aimed to help build a movement for their liberation.
item.dc:creator: KERRY MANDERS

item.title: Spain Gets a Crash Course in a Former Colony’s Art
item.description: Several shows running across Madrid are asking viewers to think differently about the art of Peru, and Spain’s own history.
item.dc:creator: MAYA JAGGI

item.title: Nonfiction: New Directions for American Foreign Policy
item.description: Bernard-Henri Lévy’s “The Empire and the Five Kings” and Ted Galen Carpenter’s “Gullible Superpower” offer conflicting advice on where we should go from here.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL KURTZ-PHELAN
item.category: Gullible Superpower: U.S. Support for Bogus Democratic Movements (Book)
The Empire and the Five Kings: America's Abdication and the Fate of the World (Book)

item.title: Letter of Recommendation: Letter of Recommendation: Personality Cafe
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Yoshi Sodeoka. Source photographs from Getty Images.
item.description: How I found a road map to my emotions on a decade-old online message board.
item.dc:creator: JEFF IHAZA

item.title: A Savory Tart for a Fickle Season
item.media:credit: Johnny Miller for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Rebecca Jurkevich.
item.description: Using store-bought puff pastry makes this spring tart more effortless than it may appear.
item.dc:creator: ALEXA WEIBEL

item.title: The New Health Care: Can Doctors Talk Teenagers Out of Risky Drinking?
item.media:description: Excessive drinking accounts for more than 4,300 deaths among adolescents each year in the United States.
item.description: The answer is worth knowing. The research is lacking.
item.dc:creator: AARON E. CARROLL

item.title: Modern Monetary Theory Finds an Embrace in an Unexpected Place: Wall Street
item.media:description: Money managers, chief executives and business analysts maintain that modern monetary theory offers important insights. Far from finding it fanciful or deranged, they are using M.M.T. to build economic forecasts and even trading strategies.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: M.M.T.’s fans include Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Bernie Sanders — and financial analysts at Goldman Sachs, Nomura and GMO.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA COHEN

item.title: Doctors: Rituals of Honor in Hospital Hallways
item.media:description: Employees at the University of Vermont Medical Center line the hallway for an honor walk for a dying patient whose organs will be donated to others.
item.description: Hospitals across the United States are holding honor walks to show respect to patients at the end of life who are donating organs to others.
item.dc:creator: TIM LAHEY, M.D.

item.title: The Races Are Virtual but the Running Is Real
item.description: Participants in virtual races run whenever they can, wherever they can, and say they still have some of the sense of being part of a crowd, even if they’re running alone.
item.dc:creator: JEN A. MILLER
